snp4.14:1.1: “Great hermit, I ask you, the Kinsman of the Sun,
snp4.14:1.2: about seclusion and the state of peace.
snp4.14:1.3: How, having seen, is a mendicant quenched,
snp4.14:1.4: not grasping anything in this world?”
snp4.14:2.1: “They would cut off the idea, ‘I am the thinker,”
snp4.14:2.3: “which is the root of all concepts of identity due to proliferation.
snp4.14:2.4: Ever mindful, they would train to remove
snp4.14:3.1: Regardless of what things they know,
snp4.14:3.3: they wouldn’t be proud because of that,
snp4.14:3.4: for that is not extinguishment, say the good.
snp4.14:4.1: They wouldn’t let that make them conceited,
snp4.14:4.2: thinking themselves better or worse or alike.
snp4.14:5.1: A mendicant would find peace inside themselves,
snp4.14:5.2: and not seek peace from another.
snp4.14:5.3: For one at peace inside themselves,
snp4.14:5.4: there’s no picking up, whence putting down?
snp4.14:6.1: Just as, in the mid-ocean deeps
snp4.14:6.2: no waves arise, it stays still;
snp4.14:6.3: so too one unstirred is still—
snp4.14:6.4: a mendicant would nurse no pride at all.”
snp4.14:7.1: “He whose eyes are open has explained
snp4.14:7.2: the truth he witnessed, where adversities are removed.
snp4.14:7.3: Please now speak of the practice, sir,
snp4.14:7.4: the monastic code and immersion in samādhi.”
snp4.14:8.2: they’d turn their ears from village gossip.
snp4.14:8.3: They wouldn’t be greedy for flavors,
snp4.14:8.4: nor possessive about anything in the world.
snp4.14:9.2: a mendicant would not lament at all.
snp4.14:9.3: They wouldn’t pray for another life,
snp4.14:9.4: nor tremble in the face of dangers.
snp4.14:10.1: When they receive food and drink,
snp4.14:10.4: nor worry about not getting them.
snp4.14:11.2: they’d avoid remorse and not be negligent.
snp4.14:11.4: in quiet places to sit and rest.
snp4.14:12.2: but, being keen, would apply themselves to wakefulness.
snp4.14:12.3: They’d give up sloth, illusion, mirth, and play,
snp4.14:13.1: They wouldn’t cast Artharvaṇa spells, interpret dreams
snp4.14:13.3: My followers would not decipher animal cries, practice healing,
snp4.14:14.2: a mendicant would not pride themselves when praised.
snp4.14:15.1: They’d not stand for buying and selling;
snp4.14:15.2: a mendicant would not speak ill at all.
snp4.14:15.3: They wouldn’t linger in the village,
snp4.14:15.4: nor cajole people from desire for profit.
snp4.14:16.1: A mendicant would be no boaster,
snp4.14:17.1: They wouldn’t be led into lying,
snp4.14:17.3: And they’d never look down on another
snp4.14:17.4: because of livelihood, wisdom, or precepts and vows.
snp4.14:18.1: Though provoked from hearing much talk
snp4.14:18.2: from ascetics saying all different things,
snp4.14:18.4: for the virtuous do not retaliate.
snp4.14:19.2: inquiring, a mendicant would always train mindfully.
snp4.14:19.4: they’d not be negligent in Gotama’s bidding.
snp4.14:20.1: For he is the undefeated, the champion,
snp4.14:20.2: seer of the truth as witness, not by hearsay—
snp4.14:20.3: that’s why, being diligent, they would always respectfully train
